Authors: Kurniawan R., Budiastuti D., Hamsal M., Kosasih W.
Title: The impact of balanced agile project management on firm performance: the mediating role of market orientation and strategic agility
Source title: Review of International Business and Strategy
Affiliations: Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kurniawan, R., Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Hamsal, M., Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia; Kosasih, W., Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta Barat, Indonesia
Abstract: Purpose: This study aims to examine the impact of balanced agile project management (balanced APM) on firm performance through the mediating role of market orientation and strategic agility of medium and large telecommunication technology providers in Indonesia. Design/methodology/approach: Research data was collected from the executive management of telecommunication technology providers in Indonesia via a questionnaire survey to obtain 150 valid questionnaires for analysis. This study analyzed the overall model fit through confirmatory factor analysis and causal relationships through structural equation modeling. Findings: The results indicate that market orientation mediates the link between balanced APM and strategic agility and that strategic agility mediates the link between market orientation and firm performance. Research limitations/implications: The choice of single telecommunication industry in a single country, Indonesia, provides a limitation on external validity. It is, therefore, suggested to extend the research efforts to other industry sectors in multi-country environments. Originality/value: This study extends the knowledge about agile project management by embracing balancing control enforcement and tests it empirically. This study also re-conceptualizes strategic agility to embrace business partner switching capability and market orientation to embrace the inter-partner coordination dimension. Finally, the results highlight that agile project management needs to be framed by market orientation to create higher value for customers. However, market orientation alone is not enough and that the organization requires strategic agility to achieve firm performance. © 2020, Emerald Publishing Limited.
Author Keywords: Balanced agile project management; Firm performance; Firm performance; Market orientation; Strategic agility; Telecommunication
Funding Text 1: The authors are grateful to the Co-Editors, Assoc. Prof Hussain Rammal and Professor Elizabeth Rose, for their guidance and to the two anonymous reviewers for their comments and suggestions.

Authors: Agustiana F., Budiastuti D.
Title: The influence of dynamic capability and collaboration strategy on the company positional advantage (A study of airports in Indonesia)
Source title: International Journal of Advanced Science and Technology
Authors with affiliations: Agustiana, F.; Budiastuti, D.
Abstract: The service performance of several airports under the auspices of Angkasa Pura is on par with other world class airports. It is important to create a company positional advantage for airports in Indonesia. But there are still facts about the problem with this. In this regard, the purpose of this study is to examine the effect of dynamic capability and collaboration strategy on company position advantages in the airport industry in Indonesia. The research design is quantitative research approaches. The type of research used in this study is verification. The survey method applied is an explanatory survey. The unit analysis in this study is airports in Indonesia. The observation unit is the airport management in Indonesia. The research data collected was in the time span of cross section / one shoot. The population in this study is all airports in Indonesia. Samples is taken as many as 50 airports. Analysis of causality in this study using Partial Least Square. The results of study reveals that the company position positional advantage is more dominantly formed by collaboration strategy and supported by dynamic capability. The results of this study have implications for airport management that the development of company position advantages can be carried out by developing collaboration strategies, especially in terms of cooperation with institutions, followed by cooperation with logistics and transportation vectors, regional airports, private stakeholders, airlines, and tour operators. These efforts are supported by the development of dynamic capability, which prioritizes to the aspects of reconfiguration strategy, seizing capacity and sensing capability. © 2020 SERSC.
Author Keywords: Collaboration strategy; Company positional advantage; Dynamic capability

Authors: Wandoko W., Budiastuti D.
Title: The impact of trust and risk on e-commerce purchase intention: A multidimensional perspective
Source title: Journal of Critical Reviews
Affiliations: Management Department, Binus Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wandoko, W., Management Department, Binus Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Management Department, Binus Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Trust and perceived risk on e-commerce are already known as key factors that drive a consumer to purchase, or not, through an online shop. The merchant must strive to build trust and minimize the consumer's perceived risk. This study analyzes and evaluates the role of trust and perceived risk on a multidimensional perspective. Based on 400 samples collected through a web-survey, this study found that the dimensions of trust and perceived risk have a different role in affecting purchase intention. For example, the time dimension from variable perceived risk has no effect on the trust. However, the time dimension has significant effects on purchase intention. The findings from this study have important and practical implications for e-commerce in developing their strategies, especially in trust building and risk reduction strategy. © 2020 Innovare Academics Sciences Pvt. Ltd. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: E-Commerce; Multidimensional; Online Risk; Online Trust; Purchase Intention

Authors: Kurniawan R., Budiastuti D., Hamsal M., Kosasih W.
Title: Networking capability and firm performance: the mediating role of market orientation and business process agility
Source title: Journal of Business and Industrial Marketing
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kurniawan, R., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Hamsal, M., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Kosasih, W., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Purpose: This study aims to examine the effect of networking capability through market orientation and business process agility on the firm performance of medium and large telecommunication technology providers in Indonesia. Design/methodology/approach: Research data was collected from the executive management of telecommunication technology providers in Indonesia via a questionnaire survey to obtain 150 valid questionnaires for analysis. This study analysed the overall model fit and hypotheses through confirmatory factor analysis and structural equation modelling. Findings: The results reveal that networking capability has a positive and significant effect on market orientation. However, networking capability does not have a significant direct effect on business process agility. The results also indicate that market orientation does not have a significant direct effect on firm performance but through the mediating role of business process agility. Practical implications: The findings provide a practical foundation for the organisation’s networking capability to be framed by market orientation and business process agility to enhance firm performance. Originality/value: The results indicate that market orientation mediates the relationship between networking capability and business process agility. The findings also reveal that business process agility mediates the relationship between market orientation and firm performance. This study also reconceptualises market orientation to embody the inter-partner coordination dimension and reconceptualise business process agility to embody business partner switching capability. © 2020, Emerald Publishing Limited.
Author Keywords: Business process agility; Firm performance; Market orientation; Networking capability; Telecommunication

Authors: Kembaren J., Budiastuti D., Prabowo H., Gaol F.L.
Title: Enhancing operational performance through ERP performance
Source title: International Journal of Advanced Trends in Computer Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kembaren, J., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Gaol, F.L., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: Changes are required within the Palm Oil Company in Indonesia to achieve competitive market advantages and become a World Class Company. Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) is an integrated business process, assisting in enhancing efficiency and productivity of any organization through trust, leadership, and mobility, playing an effective role in operational performances. The aim of this study is to collect data through a survey from 79 companies doing business in oil palm plantation which are using ERP to enhance their operational performances in Indonesia. SmartPLS 3.0 software were use to complete the analysis in this study. The study found ERP implementation, organizational trust, transformational leadership and mobility strategy have greater roles in impacting the operational enhancement. Operational performances can be achieved through sustained and trusted improvements. © 2020, World Academy of Research in Science and Engineering. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: ERP; Mobility; Palm Oil; Performance; Transformational Leadership; Trust

Authors: Munir M., Abdurachman E., Budiastuti D., Alamsjah F.
Title: Empirical study of work efficiency in upstream oil and gas industry of state company
Source title: International Journal of Advanced Trends in Computer Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Department of Research in Management, BINUS University Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Munir, M., Department of Research in Management, BINUS University Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia; Abdurachman, E., Department of Research in Management, BINUS University Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Department of Research in Management, BINUS University Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia; Alamsjah, F., Department of Research in Management, BINUS University Business School, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The upstream oil and gas industry in its operations requires the work efficiency of each individual worker, in order to achieve the company’s goals. Many things can affect every worker to work efficiently, in this study raised the factor of work professionalism, work motivation, and innovative behavior as well as individual dynamic capabilities. This study will focus to determine the extent of the influence of work professionalism, work motivation, innovative behavior on work efficiency through individual dynamic capabilities. The aim of this study is to improve work efficiency of each individual worker in upstream oil and gas industry in state-owned enterprises, in order to achieve the company’s goals. © 2020, World Academy of Research in Science and Engineering. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: And Work Efficiency; Individual Dynamic Capabilities; Innovative Behavior; Work Motivation; Work Professionalism

Title: The value of a corporate university case study: Binus corporate learning and development
Source title: Journal of Advanced Research in Dynamical and Control Systems
Affiliations: School of Information System, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Faculty Member of DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asalla, L.K., School of Information System, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Faculty Member of DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Sugandi, L., School of Information System, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Elidjen, Faculty Member of DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Faculty Member of DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: We are now live in VUCA world, where there is turbulent and rapidly changing business environment. Organizations must define resources and capabilities to help choose and implement the right strategies. By fostering learning can make a difference in navigating the unknown of VUCA. Learning center becomes one of the important functions in improving the ability of employees to help organization gain the competitive advantage. Corporate Universities are increasingly emerging to answer this challenging situation, but whether the established corporate university can provide value for the organization?. This research conducted a case study on Binus Corporate Learning & Development (BCL&D) as a corporate university since 2013. It is found that corporate universities are important to conduct this survey, in order to know the gaps that exist between the programs offered and what is assessed by employees, and how corporate university communicate the value given. © 2020, Institute of Advanced Scientific Research, Inc.. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Corporate University; Value of Corporate University; VUCA

Authors: Kembaren J., Budiastuti D., Prabowo H., Gaol F.L.
Title: Enhancing operational performance through ERP performance
Source title: International Journal of Advanced Trends in Computer Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kembaren, J., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Gaol, F.L., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: Changes are required within the Palm Oil Company in Indonesia to achieve competitive market advantages and become a World Class Company. Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) is an integrated business process, assisting in enhancing efficiency and productivity of any organization through trust, leadership, and mobility, playing an effective role in operational performances. The aim of this study is to collect data through a survey from 79 companies doing business in oil palm plantation which are using ERP to enhance their operational performances in Indonesia. SmartPLS 3.0 software were use to complete the analysis in this study. The study found ERP implementation, organizational trust, transformational leadership and mobility strategy have greater roles in impacting the operational enhancement. Operational performances can be achieved through sustained and trusted improvements. © 2019, World Academy of Research in Science and Engineering. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: ERP; Mobility; Palm Oil; Performance; Transformational Leadership; Trust

Authors: Lizardo J., Prabowo H., Furinto A., Budiastuti D.
Title: Market attractiveness and collaboration strategies in improving the business performance of the digital out of home media industry in indonesia
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Authors with affiliations: Lizardo, J.; Prabowo, H.; Furinto, A.; Budiastuti, D.
Abstract: The market share of the digital out of home (hereinafter abbreviated OOH) media industry in Indonesia is dominated by 2 or 3 companies that control more than 30% in each format of the digital OOH media business. In addition, a decrease in sales prices due to competition causes the level of profitability to fall. This condition is thought to be related to problems in collaboration strategies and market attractiveness. So based on this background, this study aims to examine the effect of market attractiveness and collaboration strategies on the business performance of the digital OOH media industry in Indonesia. The type of research used in this study is verification. The unit of analysis and unit of observation in this study is the management of the company's business units which are included in the digital OOH media industry in Indonesia. The research data collected is in the time horizon that is cross-sectional / one shoot. This study uses a multivariate statistics analysis method using PLS. The study population amounted to 183, the sample was taken as many as 118 using simple random sampling which was distributed to 3 major cities namely Jakarta, Surabaya, and Bandung, based on a list of members of the population in each city as a sampling frame. The results of the study show that market attractiveness and collaboration strategies influence business performance. Collaboration strategies have a greater influence than market attractiveness in ac hieving business performance. The results of this study have implications for the management of digital OOH media industry companies that improving business performance rests on a collaboration strategy that is supported by adaptation to market attractiveness. © IJSTR 2019.
Author Keywords: Business performance; Collaboration strategy; Digital out of home (OOH) media; Market attractiveness

Authors: Arifiani L., Budiastuti I.D., Erika W.K.
Title: The effect of disruption technology, and the future knowledge management toward service innovation for telecommunication industry 4.0 in Indonesia
Source title: International Journal of Engineering and Advanced Technology
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Arifiani, L., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, I.D., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Erika, W.K., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The disruption technological creates unprecedented opportunities and challenges that will be strengthened by the convergence of digital, physical technologies that characterize the newly emerging Fourth Industrial Revolution 4.0. This emerging technology is extraordinary and has the potential to become a source of growth. The telecommunications industry 4.0 is undergoing transformational development to deal with disruptive technological challenges. Globally, quality has declined from the past few decades, a combination of a stagnant economy and an increase in the quality of income has caused dissatisfaction. Inertia services that are often suffered by large companies are often difficult to shake, customer expectations have also shifted in the market, placing the company in a difficult situation in achieving customer satisfaction, agile and innovative technological trends, cost competition, government policy, and this will increase the level of global competition. Exploration case studies and literature reviews are used to test the antecedents of Service Innovation. The study identifies that disruption of technology services offers opportunities for business development to encourage the use of Internet-based services, increasing demand for cheaper and faster internet for consumers. To facing a competitive advantage, organizations have influenced by Service Innovation with the ability to improve big data analytics and organize future knowledge management capabilities, which are agile and flexible in providing information and solutions. From the managerial perspective, this research provides a comprehensive view of what the impact of Service Innovation is on organizations, how to achieve, what variables contribute, and how to relate with performance. The authenticity of this research lies in the description of how management emerges with a practical oriented framework of how organizations must be formed to be innovative and competitive through the general arrangement of antecedents of service innovation. This study, however, has limitations because the qualitative nature and conceptual framework need to have further investigated through large-scale surveys by quantitative research. © BEIESP.
Author Keywords: Big Data Analytics; Competitive Advantage; Disruption Technology; Knowledge Management; Service Innovation

Authors: Legowo N., Abdurachman E., Iman Herwidiana K., Budiastuti D.
Title: The influence of instructor readiness, IT capability, support of LMS content, and their implications on e-learning effectiveness in a corporate university of BUMN
Source title: International Journal of Recent Technology and Engineering
Affiliations: Information Systems Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Statistics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Management Department, BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Legowo, N., Information Systems Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Abdurachman, E., Statistics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Iman Herwidiana, K., Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebun Jeruk Raya 27, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Education is needed by every individual and organization in improving the knowledge and skills of human resources to support organizational learning, and the learning process can be done in meetings in the classroom or online using IT, commonly known as e-learning. This research aims to identify the role of instructor readiness in supporting e-learning effectiveness and the influence of Support LMS content and IT Capability on perceived usefulness and perceived ease of use to support system acceptance and the success of e-learning. This research employs quantitative method. A questionnaire was distributed to 399 respondents and the unit of analysis is employees who have used the e-learning system of the corporate university. The results of the research can reveal the influence of the readiness of Instructor and Support LMS content on the application of e-learning and how e-learning is used as a learning media for interactions between learners with the instructor. The successful application of e-learning requires the instructor readiness, which includes the mastery of the technological and pedagogical aspects as a requirement of skill in teaching by using LMS. The successful implementation of e-learning effectiveness is strongly influenced by attitude toward using LMS and employee perceptions of support content that can provide benefits and easy to use by participants that will influence the attitude of participants to learn with e-learning system in a corporate university of BUMN. © BEIESP.
Author Keywords: Corporate University; E-learning effectiveness; Instructor Readiness; IT Capability; LMS Content

Authors: Hartono H., Brodjonegoro S.S., Kuncoro E.A., Budiastuti D.
Title: Competitiveness in higher education: An empirical study in Indonesia
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Affiliations: BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Bandung Institute of Technology (ITB), General of Higher Education, Indonesian Science Association (AIPI), Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hartono, H., BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Brodjonegoro, S.S., Bandung Institute of Technology (ITB), General of Higher Education, Indonesian Science Association (AIPI), Indonesia; Kuncoro, E.A., BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The influence of globalization affects all business organizations as well as non-businesses. Moreover, Higher Education Institution (HEI) is required to consistently produce new knowledge, products, or technology, so utilization of the resources as a key factor of higher education success is a necessity. The purpose of this study is to examine the key factors of HEI competitiveness. This study argues that organizational learning with the right transformational leadership and application of knowledge management along with the ability of the organization to act entrepreneurially and to behave innovatively toachieving high performance and competitiveness. This research is descriptive and verificative with explanatory survey method at accredited private HEI in DKI Jakarta. Data collection was done through documentation study, interview and questionnaire distribution. The analysis tool used is Structural Equation Modeling-Partial Least Square (SEM-PLS) with WarpPLS version 5.0 software. The results showed that HEIs could be diagnosed, understood and changed toenhance competitiveness. This study provides evidence to guide strategy development, priority, setting and planning, especially how to develop entrepreneurship culture and enhance innovative behavior with transformational and knowledge management roles. Creating appropriate transformational leadership culture and knowledge management support organization as a learning organization to change, improve and growth. © 2019, International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Competitiveness; Entrepreneurship; Innovative behavior; Knowledge management; Performance; Transformational leadership

Authors: Kosasi S., Prabowo H., Budiastuti D., Vedyanto
Title: IT Operation Services: Impacts of Maturity Levels of IT Governance on Online Stores in West Kalimantan
Source title: 2018 6th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management, CITSM 2018
Affiliations: STMIK Pontianak, Pontianak, Indonesia; Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kosasi, S., STMIK Pontianak, Pontianak, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Vedyanto, STMIK Pontianak, Pontianak, Indonesia
Abstract: The guarantee of reliable IT operation services in producing relevant, punctual, and accurate information relies on IT maturity levels. It is noted that smoothness and appropriateness of IT operation services influence rework of dissemination of information. This research included 65 online stores in West Kalimantan as the sample. Questionnaires with groups of domains of IT processes and Likert scales were used to collect the data. Managers marketing the products through online stores became the respondents. The research aimed to cognize impacts of maturity levels of IT governance on needs of IT operation services. Results indicate that values of maturity levels that are less than 2.51 are dominated by PO Domain (PO1, PO2, PO3, PO4, PO8, and PO9), AI Domain (AI4 and AI5), DS Domain (DS4 and DS5), and ME Domain (ME4). The lowest value (2.421) is at PO3 (determining IT directions). Meanwhile, the highest one (2.975) is at DS6 (identifying and allocating costs). These values of maturity levels become important indicators of perspectives on IT operation services to map structures, processes, and relationships. Management of IT resources through interrelationships of applications, information, infrastructure, and human resources is inevitably necessary. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: IT Governance; IT Operation Services; Maturity Levels; Online Stores
Index Keywords: Electronic commerce; Surveys; IT governance; IT resources; Kalimantan; Map structure; Maturity levels; Online store; Operation services; Information management

Authors: Utomo P., Budiastuti D.
Title: Practiced culture toward firm competitiveness performance: Evidence from Indonesia
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Utomo, P., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Company values and beliefs are the grounds on which a company can develop their strategy, build their structure, and establish their processes. These values and beliefs manifest in their business practices and become critical aspects for the company to attain their goals. In small and medium entrepreneurial business, culture becomes a vital role that drives their success in limited capacity and resources. We estimated our model using the partial least squares method and gathered data from 137 digital entrepreneurial firms within six months using both offline and online methods, using the Hofstede Multi Focus Model as a framework to attribute the practice-culture. The results show that there are three dominant practices reflected in start-ups that have a significant relationship with organizational competitiveness and performance: results-oriented, pragmatic approach to the customer, and professionalism. This study contributes to a more comprehensive understanding of entrepreneurial firm practices from the human resources and organizational perspectives. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press
Author Keywords: Competitiveness; Culture; Customer orientation; Hofstede multi-focus model; Organizational effectiveness; Organizational focus; Performance

Authors: Asalla L.K., Hamsal M., Budiastuti D.
Title: Building organizational innovation capability through the corporate university program
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asalla, L.K., DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia; Hamsal, M., DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., DRM, Bina Nusantara University, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: People are one of the most strategic assets for an organization, hence when they are managed well, they will be the source of an organization’s competitive advantage, and the organization that can manage and produce continual innovation will maintain its competitive edge. The number of corporate universities has substantially increased since the 90’s, and some researchers have noted that corporate universities can be a related to production of innovation. Knowledge management somehow plays an important role in managing new and existing knowledge gained from a learning activity. Bina Nusantara (BINUS) a leading organization in education business, is currently known as the only entity that has implemented a corporate university in Indonesia. This research will analyze the role of the corporate university program in building innovation capability through knowledge management; however, only limited related research has conducted empirically. Using the SEM PLS analysis method, research is conducted through the “Best Employee of BINUS” program which considers a “Best Employee” an organization’s representative who guarantees the continuity of the a corporate university program, and its organizational capability via knowledge management. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press
Author Keywords: A corporate university; Innovation capability; Knowledge management
Funding Text 1: University for the research grant that funded this study and for my (LKA’s) Supervisors: Dr. Dyah Budiastuti and Dr. Mohammad Hamsal, and also Prof. Dr. Ir. Harjanto Prabowo as Rector, for the guidance and thoughts in guiding me in writing this paper.

Authors: Sukmana N., Abdinagoro S.B., Budiastuti D.
Title: Survival through strategic performance measurement system in coal mines
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: DRM, Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sukmana, N., DRM, Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Abdinagoro, S.B., DRM, Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., DRM, Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: The research is about performance measurement system (PMS) in coal mine organizations. The purpose of this research is to test the strategic performance measurement system (SPMS) framework through a quantitative approach and to assess the level of importance of variables in the SPMS framework by examining the effect of variables of organizational culture (OCL) on SPMS mediated by activity-based costing system (ABCS) and flexibility strategy (FLS), the effect of OCL on SPMS, the effect of ABCS on organizational performance (OPF), the effect of FLS on OPF and finally the effect of ABCS on OPF. The novelty of this research is to put the ABCS and FLS as mediating variables instead of independent variables as previous researches. The framework is hypothetic-deductive research. Primary data was collected through questionnaires. A number of 150 samples of the 250 questionnaires disseminated to both coal mine companies and mining contractors were collected and processed using SEM Lisrel version 8.7. The sample population was fairly distributed to coal mine organizations as unit of analysis. The results, using SEM Lisrel, OCL as an exogenous variable is positively related to both ABCS and FLS but does not affect SPMS directly. OCL is fully mediated by both ABCS and FLS. ABCS is positively related to both SPMS and OPF. FLS is positively related to SPMS but does not affect OPF directly. The SPMS is positively related to OPF. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press
Author Keywords: Activity-based costing system; Flexibility strategy; Organizational culture; Organizational performance; Strategic performance measurement system

Authors: Atmojo R.N.P., Budiastuti D., Abbas B.S., Kosala R.
Title: The effect of E-WOM and structural assurances mediated by Guanxi towards customer behavioral loyalty
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Information Systems Department, School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Atmojo, R.N.P., Information Systems Department, School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Abbas, B.S., Industrial Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kosala, R., Computer Science Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: In this study, we found that Structural Assurances had positive and significant direct effect on guanxi formation and it had positive and significant indirect effect toward customer loyalty behavior. We also found the facts that e-WoM had a positive and significant direct effect on guanxi formation. Where e-WoM at once had a positive and significant indirect impact on the occurrence of behavioral customer loyalty. In the end, the results of this study indicated that guanxi positively and significantly influenced the occurrence of customer loyalty behavioral when conducting E-Commerce transactions in Indonesia. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press
Author Keywords: E-business; E-commerce; E-image; Management information systems; Online purchase intention; Price premium

Authors: Zakaria Amin T.M., Budiastuti D., Gautama So I., Arief M.
Title: The Role of strategic entrepreneurship, dynamic capabilities, and government policy to improve pdam’s performance in Indonesia
Source title: International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Progam, Bina Nusantara University11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Zakaria Amin, T.M., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Progam, Bina Nusantara University11480, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Progam, Bina Nusantara University11480, Indonesia; Gautama So, I., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Progam, Bina Nusantara University11480, Indonesia; Arief, M., Management Department, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Progam, Bina Nusantara University11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This research was conducted in order to minimize the developmental gap in Indonesia’s pipe drinking water supply system development. As of today, 383 of Regional Government Water Supply Companies in Indonesia, known as Perusahaan Daerah Air Minum (PDAM), are underperforming with only 36% of urban service coverage or 22,40% of national service coverage in average. This paper aims at examining the effect of the latent variables of strategic entrepreneurship, dynamic capabilities, and government policies to PDAM performance. The novelty of this research is the role of government policy as a moderating variable in the relationship between strategic entrepreneurship and dynamic capabilities as they relate to PDAM performance. The methodology used in this research is the quantitative method conducted through a descriptive and explanatory survey. The number of the sample is 120 respondents. Further data were analyzed using the SEM-PLS method with SmartPLS software. This research proved that dynamic capabilities influence PDAM performance, and indicate the need for a stronger government policy, one that would influence strategic entrepreneurship and dynamic capabilities relate to PDAM performance. These findings are intended to contribute to development of strategic management theory and a managerial implication, specifically that PDAM should apply strategic management for the improvement of their performance in order to actively participate in government programs for drinking water services. © 2019, International Journal of Scientific and Technology Research. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Drinking water; Dynamic capabilities; Government policy; PDAM performance; Strategic entrepreneurship; Strategic management

Authors: Syahrial H., Prabowo H., Budiastuti D., Gaol F.L.
Title: Information Security Policy Compliance Model at Indonesian Government Institutions: A Conceptual Framework
Source title: Lecture Notes in Electrical Engineering
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Syahrial, H., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Gaol, F.L., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The security breaches of confidential information have remained difficult to solve due to increased external and internal threats to organization. The internal threat is predominantly the result of poor employee behavior towards organization’s information security policy. If users do not comply with information security policy, security solutions lose their efficacy. The information security policy serves as a tool to provide direction on how to manage and secure all organizational operations including critical assets, infrastructure, people, and process in organizations. A major challenge for organizations is encouraging employees to comply with information security policy. The objective of this paper is to develop a model for investigating the critical factors that influence employee compliance with information security policy based on Technology Acceptance Model (TAM). Some researchers have extended TAM to include additional factors that influence behavior. In order to develop the model, we conducted a literature review and a discussion with the information security experts from the Government and Higher Education Institutions. The factors that affect employee compliance with organization’s information security policy have been identified. Through this study, we find that the TAM can be used to develop a model for investigating employee compliance with Information Security Policy by extended it with organizational and national cultures. © Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd. 2019.
Author Keywords: Employee security behavior; Information security policy; National culture; Organizational culture; Technology acceptance model
Index Keywords: Personnel; Security of data; Security systems; Conceptual frameworks; Confidential information; Government institutions; Higher education institutions; Information security policies; National cultures; Organizational cultures; Technology acceptance model; National security

Authors: Yahya F., Gaol F.L., Polla G., Budiastuti D.
Title: Implementation of PERMITAM Model to Strengthen the Adoption of Human Cloud Systems for Millennial Generation Workforces on Insurance Business
Source title: Lecture Notes in Electrical Engineering
Affiliations: Bogor, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Yahya, F., Bogor, Indonesia; Gaol, F.L., Bogor, Indonesia; Polla, G., Bogor, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Bogor, Indonesia
Abstract: Insurance is a financial product that legally binds the insurance company to pay losses of the policyholder when unfortunate situation occurs. This insurance market is often characterized by incomplete information on both market sides, which could result moral hazard behavior. The intermediaries’ system attempts to cope this situation and provide efficient information gather from the consumers. At the end, it resulted the insurance portfolio need suitable with their current risk profile. Additionally this system provides the policy contract design and claim settlement flow. The workforces operate the system also require special skills and expert in many different areas, mainly as insurance math and contract law. This requires a scalable provisioning and “de-provisioning” of human workforces, which we argue that the implementation of Human Cloud service could leverage to better position. According to US Census Bureau (2009) Millennials generations are having the highest percentage 25.47% worldwide. Recent research conduct by APJII in 2012 shows that the Millennials Generation occupied 58.4% Internet users in Indonesia. This figure believes would be more significant in recent future years resulted potential workforces. Understanding their perceived values would be important in order to maximize their potential as future workforces. Extended version of TAM is use for this study which enriches by the Perceived Millennials generation values, which we argue could lead to better understanding to this generation cohort. This extended version of TAM is call as Perceived Millennials Technology Acceptance Model (PerMiTAM). © Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd. 2019.
Author Keywords: Extended TAM; Human cloud; Insurance; Insurance intermediaries systems; PERMITAM
Index Keywords: Commerce; Contracts; Risk management; Extended TAM; Financial products; Incomplete information; Insurance companies; Insurance intermediaries; PERMITAM; Potential workforce; Technology acceptance model; Insurance

Authors: Jaya F., Arief M., Heriyati P., Budiastuti D.
Title: The effect of brand equity and perceived value to marketing mix
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Jaya, F., Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Arief, M., Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Heriyati, P., Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Department of Management, BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper aims primarily at examining the effect of brand equity and perceived value on marketing mix. The paper is written based on empirical survey with the active participations of 256 respondents who are considered as film viewers in Indonesia. Based on structural model testing with Structural Equation Modeling, one of major findings revealed from this study showed that brand equity and perceived value had significant and positive effect on marketing mix. The finding implies that it is crucial for the Indonesian film production companies to collaborate these variables to enable attracting film viewers to cinema. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press
Author Keywords: Brand equity; Indonesia film viewers; Marketing mix; Perceived value

Authors: Tampubolon N., Budiastuti D., Bandur A., Abdurachman E.
Title: Building sustained competitive advantage through technology resources and international competitiveness
Source title: International Journal of Mechanical Engineering and Technology
Affiliations: BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tampubolon, N., BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Bandur, A., BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Abdurachman, E., BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Crude palm oil is one of the mainstays of Indonesia's exports. In the midst of intense competition with vegetable oil producing countries in the world, Indonesia must have international competitiveness which is strongly supported by the technology in order to achieve a sustained competitive advantage. The major purpose of this paper is to examine the direct effect of technological resources to international competitiveness and sustained competitive advantage as well as measure the mediating effect of international competitiveness in the relationship between technological resources and sustained competitive advantage. For these purposes, an empirical survey was conducted with the active participation of 82 palm oil industries in Indonesia. In addition to the survey, in-depth interviews were conducted to follow up the quantitative results. On the basis of path analysis with SmartPLS, technology resources had positive and significant effect to sustained competitive advantage. This study suggests the importance of technological resources in achieving sustained competitive advantage on the part of palm oil industries in developing countries. © IAEME Publication.
Author Keywords: Indonesia; International competitiveness; Palm oil industry; Sustained competitive advantage; Technological resources

Authors: Kosasi S., Budiastuti D., Prabowo H., Bandur A.
Title: Improving IT service management in higher education
Source title: International Journal of Mechanical Engineering and Technology
Affiliations: Information System, STMIK Pontianak, Merdeka Street, Pontianak, 78111, Indonesia; Management Department, BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kosasi, S., Information System, STMIK Pontianak, Merdeka Street, Pontianak, 78111, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Bandur, A., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper aims primarily at examining the mediating role of the information technology (IT) governance in the effect of IT adoption to IT service management. For this major purpose, both dimensions of quantitative and qualitative research were applied including an empirical survey with active participation of 99 private Colleges of Informatics and Computer Management in Indonesia. In addition to the survey, follow up interviews were conducted with the College Heads and Study Program Heads. Results of quantitative data analysis affirm that IT governance had positive and significant mediating effect on the improvement of IT service management. It was also found that the adoption of IT had high positive and significant direct effect on both IT governance and IT governance. This paper suggest the signicance of IT adoption in the efforts of improving IT service management of higher education institutions in both developing and developed countres. © IAEME Publication.
Author Keywords: Indonesia; IT Governance; IT Innovation Adoption; IT Service Management

Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Budiastuti, D., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper aims at examining the effect of e-Tailer quality on customers’ e-satisfaction, which in turn impacts the creation of customers’ attitudinal loyalty. The study uses an empirical survey with the active participation of 283 respondents. Using Structural Equation Modelling (SEM) analysis, this study indicates that e-Tailer quality has a positive correlation and significant effect on the formation of customers’ e-satisfaction. Furthermore, e-satisfaction is positively correlated and has a substantial impact on the formation of attitude-based customer loyalty. Interestingly, e-Tailer quality does not have a fully significant effect on the formation of attitudinal loyalty. Only platform quality dimensions have a considerable impact on the formation of attitudinal loyalty. Third-party e-Marketplace companies are alleged to have a significant influence on the creation of consumer-based loyalty in the realm of C2C business in Indonesia. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Attitudinal loyalty; Digital ecosystem; E-commerce; E-satisfaction; E-tailer quality; Indonesia; Platform quality

Title: The role of electronic word-of-mouth on customer confusion in increasing purchase intention
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities

Abstract: This study discusses the antecedents of consumer confusion on purchase intention, namely e-WOM (Electronic word of mouth). This research is aimed at exploring the effect of consumer confusion towards purchase intention moderated by omni-channel integration. Inspired by the new concept of omni-channel, this study developed a model of consumer confusion to increase purchase intention. Data was collected from a survey of 442 consumers, and SmartPLS was used as a Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) tool to analyse data. As a hypothetical development about omni-channel integration as a part of the e-quality service, this study developed three hypotheses. The results of this study showed that e-WOM has a significant impact on (1) consumer confusion, (2) purchase intention mediated by consumer confusion, and (3) purchase intention mediated by consumer confusion and moderated by quality of omni-channel integration quality. The findings of this study differed from those of previous research. The various opinions and information obtained by consumers through e-WOM increased their confusion, and thus made it difficult for them to make purchasing decisions. In Indonesia, consumers were unaware of the excellent omni-channel services, which improved speed and convenience of purchase process. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Consumer confusion; Electronic word of mouth; Omni-channel integration quality; Purchase intention

Authors: Kosasi S., Prabowo H., Budiastuti D.
Title: Improving information performance of schools in higher education through IT service management
Source title: 2017 5th International Conference on Cyber and IT Service Management, CITSM 2017
Affiliations: STMIK Pontianak, Pontianak, Indonesia; Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kosasi, S., STMIK Pontianak, Pontianak, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Universitas Bina Nusantara, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: A rising number of private schools of informatics management and computing in Indonesia are not accompanied by the accreditation grades. The fact shows that none of the 197 schools has obtained accreditation grade A. Moreover, 71.57% of these schools are still accredited with grade C. This condition reveals that there has been no synchronization and interoperability of producing information for the need of processing the academic data. The problem of the research proposal was formulated to (a) produce a new research model regarding influences of IT innovation adoption and IT governance on IT service management in improving information performance of schools; (b) create a hypothetical testing design to cognize influences of every variable in this research. The research aim was to analyze the magnitude of relationships and influences of IT service management based upon supports and deliveries of information services becoming dominant factors improving information performance of schools. The research was designed with an explanatory survey of analyzed units of organizations. Furthermore, the research applied a mixed (quantitative and qualitative) method and concurrent triangulation strategy. Computed quantitative data were obtained from a sample of 55 schools determined through a simple random sampling technique. Strengthening the quantitative analysis, qualitative measurement was conducted through in-depth interviews and FGDs (Focus Group Discussions) with 5 informants in the sample. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Information Performance; IT Governance; IT Innovation Adoption; IT Service Management
Index Keywords: Accreditation; Data handling; Information services; Innovation; In-depth interviews; Information Performance; IT governance; It innovation adoptions; IT service management; Qualitative measurements; Research proposals; Simple random sampling; Societies and institutions

Authors: Tjhin V.U., Abbas B.S., Budiastuti D., Kosala R.
Title: Mobile usability: An antecedent for influencing purchase intention moderated by omni-channel integration quality
Source title: 2017 3rd International Conference on Information Management, ICIM 2017
Affiliations: School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Industrial Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tjhin, V.U., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Abbas, B.S., Industrial Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Kosala, R., BINUS Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The new concept of omni-channel has inspired researchers to develop a model of consumer confusion to increase purchase intention. Previous studies were tested that the omni-channel integration quality can improve customer satisfaction. As a novelty, this study introduced omni-channel integration as a moderating variable that influence consumer confusion to the intention of purchase. This paper constituted a hypothetical development about the proposed omni-channel integration as a part of the e-quality service. This proposed research aimed to explore the effect of consumer confusion towards purchase intention moderated by omni-channel integration. Three hypotheses were modeled in this research proposal. The future results of this research are expected to be a significant contribution towards business, science, and society. © 2017 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Consumer confusion; Mobile usability; Omni-channel integration quality; Purchase intention
Index Keywords: Customer satisfaction; Information management; Purchasing; Sales; Consumer confusion; Mobile usability; Purchase intention; Quality services; Research proposals; Integration

Authors: Kembaren J., Budiastuti D.
Title: Role of Mobility Strategy in moderating the effect of ERP performance to operational performance: (Study in Indonesian palm oil plantation industries)
Source title: Proceedings of 2016 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2016
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kembaren, J., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Indonesia has an important role in the world's palm oil industry. One way of efficiency in business processes of the company is to make the implementation of Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), which aims to increase the productivity and effectiveness. Palm oil plantation companies implementing ERP hope that it will provide great benefits in operational performance, but the performance has not been measure yet that ERP has been performed. Organizational Trust and Transformational Leadership are needed to get the ERP performed in the organization. The Mobility Strategy surely can be the leap that can moderating the effect of ERP performance to the Operational Performance. © 2016 IEEE.

Abstract: The new concept of omni-channel has inspired researchers to develop a model of consumer confusion to increase purchase intention. Previous studies were tested that the omni-channel integration quality can improve customer satisfaction. As a novelty, we introduced omni-channel integration as a moderating variable that influence consumer confusion to the intention of purchase. This paper constituted a hypothetical development about the proposed omni-channel integration as a part of the e-quality service. This proposed research aimed to explore the effect of consumer confusion towards purchase intention moderated by omni-channel integration. In addition, this study discussed about the antecedent of consumer confusion to the intention of purchase, namely e-WOM. Three hypotheses were modeled in this research proposal. The future results of this research were expected to be a significant contribution towards business, science, and society. © 2016 IEEE.

Authors: Sudrajat D., Budiastuti D., Setiadi N.J., Supeli A.
Title: The effect of integrated information technology on innovative capability and its impact on firm performance
Source title: Proceedings of 2016 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2016
Affiliations: School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Business and Management Faculty, Widyatama University, Bandung, Indonesia; Griffith Business School, Griffith UniversityQueensland, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Sudrajat, D., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., School of Business Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Setiadi, N.J., Business and Management Faculty, Widyatama University, Bandung, Indonesia; Supeli, A., Griffith Business School, Griffith UniversityQueensland, Australia
Abstract: The firm performance constituted a serious problem for Indonesian Logistics Service Providers (LSP), so that the performance improvement is important and urgent matter for the companies particularly in the context of ASEAN Economic Community. Conceptually, some previous researches showed that the firm performance was influenced by innovative capability and the capability influenced by resources. The researches also showed that not all resources had positive and significant effect on innovative capability. The integrated IT as one of resources and it must be owned by logistics service provider in Indonesia in accordance with government regulation. This research aimed to assess the effect of integrated information technology (IT) on firm performance pass through innovative capability. This research used causal research methodology and analyzed by Partial Least Squares (Smart-PLS 2.0). It was found that integrated IT had positive and significant effect on firm performance pass through innovative capability. It showed that resources must be modified into capabilities in order to have a positive and significant impact on firm performance. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Dynamic Capability Theory; Firm Performance; Innovative Capability; Integrated IT; Resource-Based Theory
Index Keywords: Information management; Least squares approximations; Dynamic capabilities; Firm Performance; Innovative capability; Integrated IT; Resource-based theory; Logistics

Authors: Wandoko W., Abbas B.S., Budiastuti D., Kosala R.
Title: Online trust building through third party trust transfer and third party protection
Source title: Journal of Physics: Conference Series
Affiliations: School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Industrial Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wandoko, W., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Abbas, B.S., Industrial Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Kosala, R., Binus Business School, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: The primary objective of this research is to develop an online trust building mechanism for SME (Small Medium Enterprise). Trust is very important in e-commerce. The nature of online shopping has a greater uncertainty than offline shopping. Seeing as there is an uncertainty that can produce risks, a prospective buyer's trust is needed. A lot of people's unwillingness to shop online is caused by their lack of trust toward e-commerce. E-commerce is said to be one of the ways for SME to compete with bigger companies. However, building trust requires immense time and cost. SME with limited resources may experience difficulties in building trust just with their own resources. Base on literature research that needs to be validated in next research, we found that trust can be built through trust transfer from the reputable and well-known trust-mark issuer, and third party protection such as escrow account service and credit card issuer. © Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Index Keywords: Commerce; Account services; Literature researches; Online shopping; Primary objective; Prospective buyers; Small medium enterprise; Third parties; Trust transfer; Electronic commerce

Authors: Budiastuti D., Prabowo H.
Title: Quality of transformation of knowledge as part of knowledge management system: (Research in private university in Jakarta)
Source title: Lecture Notes in Electrical Engineering
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Budiastuti, D., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The main activity in education is the transfer of knowledge from educators with learners and among learners themselves. The knowledge can be in the form of explicit or implicit. On the other hand, the implementation of Knowledge Management conducted in almost all business and social activities, including in the field of education. This study aimed to get an idea of the condition of the implementation of the transformation of knowledge and develop knowledge management model of private university in Jakarta. Data were analyzed using descriptive tool “Radar”. © Springer Nature Singapore Pte Ltd. 2017.
Author Keywords: Knowledge transformation; Model KM
Index Keywords: Knowledge based systems; Jakarta; Knowledge management model; Knowledge management system; Knowledge transformation; Social activities; Transfer of knowledge; Knowledge management

Authors: Margaretha, Budiastuti D., Sahroni T.R.
Title: Application of theory of constraint supply chain replenishment system in fast moving consumer goods company
Source title: International Journal of Supply Chain Management
Affiliations: Industrial Engineering Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Research in Management Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Margaretha, Industrial Engineering Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Research in Management Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Sahroni, T.R., Industrial Engineering Binus Graduate Programs, Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan 9, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Today's market competitiveness has reached its peak since the rapid growth of industrial and technology development. The market dominance aims to fulfill the consumer supply and demand, by giving excellent service, such as stabilizing the finished goods inventory level in the right time and quantity. This study was conducted in one of the Fast Moving Consumer Goods (FMCG) Company in Indonesia which has several problems in supplying their product to market. Actual market condition and demand become the main factor why the company is unable fulfilling the right product to its consumer, despite the Production Planning and Inventory Control (PPIC) segment has made the right production target based on the Purchase Order and Selling Target from Distributors Company. Thus, further development by combining supply chain management system with several theory of constraints is required to manage the material inventory and finished goods, which meet the consumer needs such as integrated master production schedule, market demand condition, finished goods inventory, and material replenishment by suppliers. © ExcelingTech Pub, UK.
Author Keywords: Fast Moving Consumer Goods (FCMG); Forecasting; Inventory; Supply chain management; Theory of constraint
References: Cary, S.N., (2009) "Production & Operations Management", , Tata McGraw Hill, 4th Edition; Steven, N., (2001) "Production and Operations Analysis", , McGraw Hill, 4th Edition; Sipper, D., Bulfin, R.L., Jr., (1997) "Production: Planning, Control, amd Integration", , McGraw Hill, New York; Jay, H., Barry, R., (2009) "Operations Management", , Pearson, 9th Edition; Goldratt, E.M., (1990) What is this thing called the Theory of Constraints?, , North River Press, Croton-on-Hudson, NY; Zeynep, S.T., Noyan, G.S., Ozalp, V., "Theory of Constraints Literature Review" (2014) International Journal Strategic Management Conference, , Procedia; Senator, B.N., (2006) "Sistem Inventori", , ITB; Wu, H.H., Chen, C.P., Tsai, C.H., Tsai, T.P., "A Study of Theory of Constraints Supply Chain Replenishment System," (2010) International Journal of Academic Research in Accounting, Finance and Management Sciences, 3 (3), pp. 82-92; Russel, R.S., Taylor, B.W., (2011) Operations Management, , Wiley; Tang, O., Robert, W., "Planning and replanning the master production schedule under demand uncertainty" (2005) International Journal of Production Economics, 78 (3), pp. 323-334; Hill, J.A., William, L., Berry David, A., "Revising The Master Production Schedule in Sequence Dependent Processes" (2003) International Journal of Production Research, 41 (9), pp. 2021-2035

Authors: Kurniawan Y., Prabowo H., Budiastuti D.
Title: Knowledge conversion system for hospitals (A conceptual model)
Source title: Advanced Science Letters
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Kurniawan, Y., Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Bina Nusantara University, Jl KH Syahdan No 9, Kemanggisan, Jakarta Barat  11480, Indonesia
Abstract: The hospital is close essentially related to the knowledge-intensive property, it is shown by the professionals at the hospital as a key for providing quality care to patients. Basically there are many problems that occur in hospitals in Indonesia related to the knowledge owned by the professionals at the hospital. The hospital needs to develop knowledge management systems based on knowledge conversion system as a basis for development of systems that can help to improve the process of medical or non-medical services at the hospital. This study indicates that the conceptual model of KM that suitable with these components, and the close correlation between professional workers (knowledge workers) and knowledge management performance for providing quality services. © 2016 American Scientific Publishers All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Conversion; Hospital; Knowledge management

Authors: Wadjdi A.F., Budiastuti D.
Title: E-gov adoption model of the military organization in Indonesia
Source title: Proceedings - 2015 International Conference on Science in Information Technology: Big Data Spectrum for Future Information Economy, ICSITech 2015
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Wadjdi, A.F., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Not only being implemented in the government ministries and agencies, e-gov is also implemented in the military sector in terms of service delivery to the public. Many researchers have studied and proposed models of e-gov adoption in order to predict or explain user behavior, or to formulate a strategy based on Technology Acceptance Model (TAM). Small research number has been established to analyze factors influencing e-gov adoption in military organization. Thus, this work inspects the applicability of the TAM with many constructs under technology-organization-environment framework that predict a suitable model to the Indonesian military in the context of e-gov adoption. The Dematel method was used to figure out the factors that affect the acceptance of e-gov by military personnel using a survey sample of 42 ICT administrators of TNI (Ministry of Defense, Army, Navy, and Air Forces). Moreover, Structural Equation Modelling was used to analyze data of 400 TNI personnel to validate dominant factors resulted from the Dematel. The findings indicate that competitive pressure, self-efficacy of computer, ease of use, e-readiness, usefulness, service quality, attitude, and behavioral intention were valid constructs of e-gov adoption in Indonesian military organization. The study recommends a further research of e-gov adoption strategy that focuses on the implementation of those factors on the level of organizational units within the military. © 2015 IEEE.
Author Keywords: e-gov; military; technology acceptance model; technologyorganization-environment framework
Index Keywords: Big data; Behavioral intention; Competitive pressure; military; Military organizations; Organizational units; Structural equation modelling; Technology acceptance model; Technology-organization-environment frameworks; Behavioral research

Title: Research plan development concerning e-image impact towards online purchase intention and premium pricing strategies in Indonesia community based online market
Source title: Proceedings - 2015 International Conference on Science in Information Technology: Big Data Spectrum for Future Information Economy, ICSITech 2015
Affiliations: School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Business and Management, Prasetiya Mulya Business School, South-Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Department of Law, Christian University of Indonesia, East-Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Atmojo, R.N.P., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Mahesa, R., School of Business and Management, Prasetiya Mulya Business School, South-Jakarta, Indonesia; Wandoko, W., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Tjhin, V.U., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Prabowo, H., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Gaol, F.L., School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Koeswidi Astuti, T.N., Department of Law, Christian University of Indonesia, East-Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: The Gregg and Walczak definition about e-image has been inspired us to examine their theoretical model in a different digital marketplace environment. As a novelty, we introduced the Real-Time Support Assistance (RTOSA) concept as a supplementary moderating variable. This paper constitutes hypothetical development about the proposed RTOSA and contains a brief description of Indonesia largest online community forum that projected as our online experimental research dioramas. This proposed research aims to explore the e-image effect towards consumer willingness to do the online transaction and the seller capability to adjust pricing premium moderated by RTOSA and also product type differences. Six hypotheses were modeled in this research proposal. The future results of this research are expected to be a significant contribution towards society, business, and science. © 2015 IEEE.

Authors: Atmojo R.N.P., Tjhin V.U., Wandoko W., Budiastuti D., Polla G., Mahesa R., Astuti T.N.K.
Title: Rekening Bersama (RekBer) the Indonesian escrow service of money
Source title: International Journal of Multimedia and Ubiquitous Engineering
Affiliations: School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Department of Statistics, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; School of Business and Management, Prasetiya Mulya Business School, South-Jakarta, Indonesia; Department of Law, The Christian University of Indonesia, East-Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Atmojo, R.N.P., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Tjhin, V.U., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Wandoko, W., School of Information Systems, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Polla, G., Department of Statistics, Bina Nusantara University, West-Jakarta, Indonesia; Mahesa, R., School of Business and Management, Prasetiya Mulya Business School, South-Jakarta, Indonesia; Astuti, T.N.K., Department of Law, The Christian University of Indonesia, East-Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: That was a common thing when Escrow Service of Money (ESM) providers handled by the institution that has a legal aspect (structural assurance) to operates their business activities. However, how if the bank-like service agency operates by the individual, performed online and does not have some guaranteeing assets? How they do warrant their customers that they will not violate the consumer trusts? In addition, did the customers trust them? In this paper appointed a case study of the Rekening Bersama (RekBer) phenomenon as Indonesian ESM. Where, most of them ran the bank-like business without forming a legal entity as a reliable guarantee. In spite of that, we found a unique behavioral pattern that either incorporated RekBer or individual RekBer has the same opportunity to being trusted by their trustors. © 2016 SERSC.

Authors: Budiastuti D.
Title: Development model of innovation capability and management of innovation (A study case in BINUS university)
Source title: Advanced Science Letters
Affiliations: School of Business Management, BINUS University11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Budiastuti, D., School of Business Management, BINUS University11480, Indonesia
Abstract: BINUS University, a top leading university in system development, teaching quality and prime creation, faces challenges in creating products, programs, and even service processes that are innovative to satisfy the society’s need for higher education. This research aims to evaluate the innovation capability, management of innovation status, as well as to design a strategy and a model of innovation capability and management of innovation in BINUS University. The research is implemented to all Faculty Members and is analyzed by statistic descriptive. The result of this research has shown that BINUS University has succeeded well in innovation capability and management of innovation. Thus, is becoming a surplus point for the stakeholder. Even so, BINUS University should implement the innovation development model consistently to improve their capability to innovate and utilize the management of innovation to create innovative products. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Development model; Innovation capability; Management of innovation
References: Alstete, J.W., Meyer, J.P., (2010) Journal of Information and Knowledge Management, 9, p. 1; Azahari, A., (2000) Jurnal Pendidikan Dan Kebudayaan, p. 23; Bowen, G.W., (2006) University and Their Leadership, , Princeton University Press; Brynjolfsson, E., Saunders, A., (2010) Wired for Innovation, , The MIT Press, Cambridge, Massachusetts London, England; Budiastuti, D., (2013) Membangun Strategi Bersaing Dan Strategi Kerjasama Melalui Manajemen Pengetahuan Dan Manajemen Inovasi Dalai Upaya Pencapaian Kinerja Perguruan Tinggi, , Penelitian di Perguruan Tinggi Swasta DKI Jakarta, Penelitian Disertasi; Carter, C., Scarbrough, H., (2001) Education+Training, 43, p. 215; Christensen, M.C., Eyring, J.H., (2011) The Innovative University, , Jossey-Bass A Wiley Imprint, San Fransisco; Fontana, A., (2011) Innovate We Can! Authors: Ongowarsito H., Budiastuti D., Suryanto
Title: Development of mobile school parent desk using 7C framework
Source title: Advanced Science Letters
Affiliations: Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Ongowarsito, H., Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Budiastuti, D., Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia; Suryanto, Binus University, Jakarta, 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: Customers are very important for the success of an educational institution or company. An educational institution must establish a good relationship with the prospective customer and existing customers in order to maintain and grow customer loyalty. The purpose of this research is to identify the features of an Mobile Parent Desk application needed by parents and school, designing Mobile Parent Desk application according to the needs of parents and the school, implementation plan of a Mobile Parent Desk application. Respondents in this study consisted of two groups: parents and school. The methods of analysis used in the research are factor analysis, 7C framework, and descriptive statistics. The final result of this research is an e-CRM application-Mobile Parent Desk with features developed from 7C framework. © 2015 American Scientific Publishers. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 7C framework; e-CRM; Factor analysis; Mobile parent desk
